Metadata.Title: Avoid Universal Data Link (UDL) Files Where Possible
Metadata.DirectLink: Avoid Universal Data Link (UDL) Files Where Possible
Metadata.Priority: J.D. Meier, Alex Mackman, Blaine Wastell, Prashant Bansode, Chaitanya Bijwe

Content.Data:
Applies to

  • ADO.NET 2.0

What to Do

You should avoid supplying connection information for an OleDbConnection in a Universal Data Link (UDL) file.

If you must use UDL files, restrict access to them by configuring an access control list (ACL) that restricts access to the account under which your application runs.

Why

UDL files are not encrypted and expose connection string information in clear text. Because a UDL file is an external file-based resource to your application, it cannot be secured by using the .NET Framework.

When

You should avoid supplying connection information for an OleDbConnection in a Universal Data Link (UDL) file, wherever possible.

How

If you must use UDL files, restrict access to them by configuring an access control list (ACL) that restricts access to the account under which your application runs..

  • Assign appropriate permissions to the UDL files.
    • Only administrators should have full access to the UDL files. 
    • The Account under which your application runs should have read only access to the UDL files. 
  • Minimize the number of individuals who can manipulate or access the UDL files.  Authorize access only to highly trusted accounts such as administrators.

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
